Award.AwardTitle: A Simulation Model for Understanding Prevention and Treatment of Depression Among HIV+ Women

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines the allocation of resources to the treatment and prevention of HIV/AIDS and the role of screening and treatment for depression among women living with HIV (WLWH). HIV is no longer a death sentence for those infected, and the disease is becoming like other chronic diseases. As a result, comorbidities are becoming a greater concern. Of common comorbidities, depression is arguably the most important, especially for women. Depression shapes key aspects of HIV care, such as retention in care. This project will evaluate the impact of screening and treatment of depression among WLWH on the public and social costs of HIV/AIDS and on the allocation of resources to treatment and prevention of HIV. In doing so, we consider not just the costs of treatment but also the productivity costs-the effect on employment, disability, and other public expenditures. Our research approach involves integration of simulation modeling with new methodologies in cost effectiveness research, including a portfolio-based approach.

When completed, this project will answer key questions: (1) What allocation of HIV/AIDS-related expendi-tures between treatment and prevention produces the best levels of HIV/AIDS and employment among women in the community? (2) What portion of a budget should be allocated to identifying and treating depression among HIV+ women? (3) How would screening for depression among HIV+ women affect expenditures on HIV treatment and on depression? (4) Do WLWH who are treated for depression remain in the labor force longer, staying off disability and public insurance? (5) How does the best mix of expenditures depend on community characteristics, such as labor market conditions and public insurance, such as the Medicaid program?

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed an Agent Based simulation model to predict how improvements in screening for and treating depression among persons who are already infected with HIV/AIDS may affect their adherence to HIV treatment and the subsequent spread of the disease. The main focus is on women living with HIV (WLWH) but contrasting information is also developed for men. The model tracks the individual members of a hypothetical cohort of HIV infected people with demographic characteristics of the HIV infected U.S. population. It works through the various feedback loops and personal interactions that begin with initial HIV infection and then it proceeds through seeking treatment, possibly becoming depressed, possibly being screened for depression and receiving treatment, adhering to HIV treatment, changing one’s risky sexual behavior in response to depression, changing one’s viral load by not adhering to HIV treatment and possibly passing on HIV to a sex partner. The model evaluates the cost utility – changes in cost relative to changes in quality adjusted life years -- of various approaches to screening for depression and the intensity of depression treatment.  The model can be extended to predict changes in employment and disability insurance due to changes in health status.

            The model is built on the AnyLogic©7 platform. Parameters for the model have been developed from published literature and two key data sources: 1) the Women's Interagency HIV Study (WIHS) and 2) the Center for Aids Research (CFAR) Network of Integrated Clinical Systems (CNICS). WIHS contains information specific to women with HIV regarding their treatment for depression and adherence to HIV treatment. CNICS has information for men and women on the rate of disease progression when they adhere to HIV treatment as well as information on the occurrence of and treatment for depression.  As of November 2016, the model is in the last stages of calibration with final results expected in the spring of 2017.
